p: Most of the identified phytochemicals in N. sativa seed oil have previously been reported to show antidiabetic, anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, anticancer, antimicrobial, anti-arthritic, anticonvulsant, antiulcer, antihypertensive, anti-nociceptive, hepatoprotective, cytotoxic, antimycomicrobial, antiparasitic, and analgesic activities (Marques et al. 2019; Caboni et al. 2012; Begum et al. 2016; Lang and Buchbauer 2012; Balamurugan et al. 2013; Muniyan and Gurunathan 2016; Saeed et al. 2012; Zhao et al. 2018; Adeoye-Isijola et al. 2018; Wu et al. 2017; Chavan et al. 2009; Yimer et al. 2019; Hadi et al. 2016; Engels and Brinkmann 2017). These compounds showed varying degrees of binding on the SARS-CoV-2 protein targets (Table 2), as revealed by the change in Gibb’s free energy values (ΔG) (Duru and Duru 2020). The FDA emergency approved drug Remdesivir (Williamson et al. 2020), administered on adults and children with suspected or confirmed cases of COVID-19, was used as a control to identify compounds with good binding affinities for the studied COVID-19 proteins. Caryophyllene oxide had the best binding affinities on 3CLpro (− 6.0 kcal/mol), NSP3 (− 6.3 kcal/mol), NSP9 (− 6.3 kcal/mol), and RDRP (− 6.9 kcal/mol) targets. The compound α-bergamotene gave the best binding affinity on RPIA (5.7 kcal/mol), while β-bisabolene displayed an excellent binding affinity on the ACE2 protein target. These values were very close to those obtained using the antiviral control drug. The binding affinity of β-bisabolene (− 8.0 kcal/mol) was almost similar to Remdesivir (− 8.1 kcal/mol) on the ACE2 target. This observation is an indication that β-bisabolene could prevent the interaction of the spike glycoprotein of the virus with the ACE2 protein of the human host cell, thereby preventing infection of the host.
